questionText: Shakespeare invented words like 'bedazzled' and 'eyeball'; modern writers are just lazy.
Dr. Seuss wrote ‘Green Eggs and Ham’ with only 50 different words; breakfast can be poetic.
J.K. Rowling’s Hogwarts letters are the ultimate example of unsolicited mail.
The Cat in the Hat shows that house-sitting is way more fun with a mischievous feline.
Alice fell down a rabbit hole, proving curiosity can literally be dangerous.
Romeo and Juliet is proof that texting your crush too soon can end tragically.
Homer wrote the Odyssey, an ancient road trip story with more monsters than traffic jams.
The Little Prince teaches that adults are weird, especially about numbers and sheep.
Sherlock Holmes solved crimes with deduction; basically the original true crime podcast host.
Dracula is just a guy with extreme dental hygiene issues.
Moby Dick proves that being obsessed with a whale is not a good life plan.
Peter Pan never grows up, showing eternal youth can be both fun and annoying.
Winnie the Pooh loves honey, teaching us that simple pleasures matter most.
The Hunger Games prove that reality TV is nothing new; dystopia existed first.
Tom Sawyer convinced others to paint his fence; genius marketing, 19th-century style.
Pride and Prejudice warns us that judgments can make life complicated… and messy.
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde prove everyone has a secret side, hopefully not murderous.
The Wizard of Oz shows that yellow brick roads lead to unexpected adventures.
Huckleberry Finn traveled down a river; sometimes the best ideas come with a boat ride.
Peter Rabbit is a bad influence on gardens everywhere.
The Chronicles of Narnia involve wardrobes, lions, and epic battle strategies.
Wuthering Heights proves love can be dramatic, stormy, and a little destructive.
Charlotte’s Web teaches friendship with spiders is socially acceptable in literature.
The Tale of Two Cities shows that revolution can be emotional and guillotine-filled.
Little Women proves that sibling rivalry and dreams go hand in hand.
The Hobbit went on a journey, showing small guys can have big adventures.
Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland includes talking animals and logical nonsense, still better than Monday mornings.
The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe show that magical wardrobes are a thing.
Charlie and the Chocolate Factory proves that chocolate can solve childhood boredom.
Matilda used telekinesis to handle adults, proving powers are handy in school.
The Little Mermaid teaches that underwater deals can be tricky.
Pinocchio’s nose grew when he lied; honesty has obvious side effects.
The Odyssey is basically a long commute filled with monsters and detours.
Hamlet questioned life, death, and everything in between; modern philosophers take notes.
The Inferno is Dante’s roadmap through hell; not recommended for a Sunday stroll.
Pippi Longstocking lives alone, defying parental supervision and expectations.
The Jungle Book proves animals can be better mentors than humans sometimes.
Goldilocks taught children that trial-and-error applies to furniture and porridge.
Robin Hood stole from the rich to give to the poor; early startup philanthropy.
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde prove everyone has a dark side, ideally less murderous.
The Wizard of Oz features flying monkeys, yellow bricks, and life lessons rolled into one.
Winnie the Pooh’s wisdom: ‘Sometimes the simplest things bring the most happiness.’
The Cat in the Hat shows that mischief is entertaining if you survive the chaos.
The Little Prince proves adults often forget the important things, like roses and friendship.

Dracula is proof that style, drama, and nocturnal habits never go out of fashion.

Shakespeare could insult someone in 10 words or less; modern Twitter might struggle.
George Orwell’s 1984 shows that Big Brother was the original nosy neighbor.
Frankenstein proves that playing with science can create family drama… and monsters.
Pride and Prejudice’s Mr. Darcy mastered brooding before it became Instagram-worthy.
Hemingway’s writing is short, direct, and makes coffee nervous for not trying hard enough.
The Great Gatsby throws parties so big even the neighbors wrote Yelp reviews.
Macbeth proves ambition and a talking dagger make for a terrible career path.
Don Quixote shows that chasing windmills is easier than chasing reality.
The Scarlet Letter proves public shaming is nothing new, and letters still sting.
Les Misérables combines singing, revolution, and heartbreak; basically a marathon of emotions.
Anna Karenina proves that trains are dramatic devices and life lessons rolled into one.
Catch-22 shows that military logic can be confusing, circular, and hilariously frustrating.
The Odyssey’s long journey has monsters, gods, and terrible GPS directions.
Brave New World warns that happiness at all costs might include too many pills.
The Iliad shows that Greek gods had more drama than modern soap operas.
To Kill a Mockingbird proves justice isn’t always fair, but courage still matters.
Fahrenheit 451 shows that book burning is never a good idea… unless dystopia is your hobby.
The Metamorphosis proves that waking up as a bug is worse than Monday mornings.
Dracula’s diary entries are the original Gothic Instagram posts.
Lord of the Flies shows that civilization collapses faster than a sandcastle in a storm.
Frankenstein’s monster shows that awkward introductions can lead to terrifying consequences.
The Divine Comedy’s Inferno is like Yelp reviews of hell; not recommended.
Jane Eyre proves that independence and stubbornness are timeless literary skills.
The Canterbury Tales feature pilgrims who gossip more than your group chat.
The Picture of Dorian Gray shows that vanity can literally ruin your face.

The Jungle Book proves that growing up in the wild is both fun and confusing.

Dracula reminds us that biting strangers isn’t socially acceptable.
Lord of the Flies shows that children alone are excellent at chaos creation.

Ulysses by James Joyce might make you question if words have too many moods.
War and Peace is long enough to qualify as a minor endurance sport.
The Brothers Karamazov is a philosophical family drama with more guilt than therapy can handle.

The Sound and the Fury teaches that perspective can break your head before it breaks your heart.
